author: Carl Sagan
text:
We live in a society exquisitely dependent on science and technology, in which hardly anyone knows anything about science.

The cosmos is within us. We are made of star-stuff. We are a way for the universe to know itself.

Science is more than a body of knowledge; it's a way of thinking — a way of skeptically interrogating the universe with a fine understanding of human fallibility.

author: Yuval Noah Harari
text:
In the twenty-first century, humans are likely to make a serious bid for immortality. The most important question in economics and politics of the coming decades will be what to do with all the superfluous people.

History began when humans invented gods, and will end when humans become gods.

Each year the US population spends more money on diets than the amount needed to feed all the hungry people in the rest of the world.

author: Stephen Hawking
text:
Intelligence is the ability to adapt to change.

We are just an advanced breed of monkeys on a minor planet of a very average star. But we can understand the universe. That makes us something very special.

The greatest enemy of knowledge is not ignorance, it is the illusion of knowledge.

author: Angela Davis
text:
I'm no longer accepting the things I cannot change. I'm changing the things I cannot accept.

We have to talk about liberating minds as well as liberating society.

It is in collectivities that we find reservoirs of hope and optimism.

author: Fareed Zakaria
text:
In an age of globalization, we need to think of the world as a whole, not just of individual countries.

The rise of illiberal democracy is one of the most striking developments of the last two decades.

The key challenge for governments today is how to make globalization work for their populations.

author: Malcolm Gladwell
text:
The tipping point is that magic moment when an idea, trend, or social behavior crosses a threshold, tips, and spreads like wildfire.

We learn by example and by direct experience because there are real limits to the adequacy of verbal instruction.

Truly successful decision making relies on a balance between deliberate and instinctive thinking.

author: Jared Diamond
text:
History followed different courses for different peoples because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among peoples themselves.

Agriculture was the worst mistake in the history of the human race.

The adoption of agriculture, supposedly our most decisive step toward a better life, was in many ways a catastrophe.

author: Atul Gawande
text:
Better is possible. It does not take genius. It takes diligence. It takes moral clarity. It takes ingenuity. And above all, it takes a willingness to try.

Our medical systems are broken. But our goals remain the same: to avoid suffering and improve quality of life.

The reality is that lives are saved by systems — by teams of people working together and making sure things don’t fall through the cracks.

author: Bill Bryson
text:
Not one of your pertinent ancestors was squashed, devoured, drowned, starved, stranded, stuck fast, untimely wounded or otherwise deflected from its life’s quest of delivering a tiny charge of genetic material to the right partner.

There are only three things that can kill a farmer: lightning, rolling over in a tractor, and old age.

The greatest gift of life is the freedom it leaves you to step out of it whenever you choose.

author: Thomas Friedman
text:
The world is flat. What happened in the early 2000s was that globalization went from being something that just happened to something that was done.

In the hyper-connected world, average is over.

When the world is flat, you can innovate without having to emigrate.
